awd_titl_txt: Institutional Transformation: Enhancing IUPUI STEM Curriculum through the Community-Engaged Learning and Ethical Reflection Framework (I-CELER)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will facilitate and research  the institutional transformation of two Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis (IUPUI) departments, Biomedical Engineering and Earth Sciences. Specifically, it will (i) promote the Integration of Community-Engaged Learning and Ethical Reflection (I-CELER) in these STEM curricula, (ii) explore the organizational impact of the project on institutional change, and (iii) analyze individual changes associated with students' and educators' ethical development. This project will increase faculty's ability to integrate philosophical reflection and community engagement within their departmental curriculum through their participation in Faculty Learning Community (FLC) meetings designed to explore the I-CELER framework. In turn, this will improve their undergraduate students' learning outcomes related to ethical development. Through a research to practice cycle, investigators will promote, explore, and iterate on techniques for embedding and teaching STEM ethics in community-engaged environments. This will provide the context in which undergraduates will design potential solutions, establish empathic relationships with community members, and simultaneously reflect upon the meanings and values affecting those relationships through the philosophical lenses of John Dewey's moral philosophy and an ethic of care. By integrating community-engaged ethical instruction into departmental curricula and investigating these effects, STEM ethics education at the investigators' institution will be infused with a new vitality leading to ethically-literate, civic-minded, and empathic cohorts of undergraduate students, educators who are confident about integrating ethics and community-engaged pedagogy in their courses, and transformed departments that incorporate ethics instruction throughout their curriculum. 

At a theoretical level, this project will inform a largely lacking ontological discourse about the ethical development of STEM students and faculty. Many prominent pedagogies in STEM ethics focus on ethical reasoning or sensitivity of students, but rarely have scholars investigated how the enactment of care practices and an authentic engagement with diversity influences the ethical subjectivities of STEM students and educators. By utilizing the I-CELER framework, Earth Sciences and Biomedical Engineering faculty will integrate ethical reflection and community engagement in their courses, thereby transforming the way disciplinary ethics are taught across the curricula. 

The project will be researched using a convergent mixed methods design and will use multiple surveys, including the DIT2 and the Civic-Minded Graduate and Professional scales, along with data derived from ethnographic methods. By situating this design within an educational research and practice cycle, annual research insights will improve the next year's intervention, which will inform refined questions and hypotheses. In sum, this project will create a tested model for transforming the teaching and learning of STEM ethics.

Intellectual Merit: To ensure the development of an exemplary generation of science, technology, engineering, & mathematics (STEM) professionals, undergraduate STEM students must learn to engage in ethical thought and action. The primary goals of this project were to (1) Develop a Faculty Learning Community to promote change in ethics instruction in STEM departments and in the ethical subjectivities of faculty and the undergraduates in their courses; (2) Identify and analyze the organizational outcomes and changes associated with the formation of ethical cultures of STEM, specifically those arising from the Faculty Learning Community; and (3) Identify and analyze individual outcomes and changes associated with the Faculty Learning Community and novel "Integrating Community-Engaged Learning and Ethical Reflection" or "I-CELER" courses to understand the processes and variables related to the ethical training and formation of STEM faculty and undergraduates. To achieve these goals, we developed and implemented a multi-year Faculty Learning Community led by our interdisciplinary team of investigators who brought backgrounds in philosophy, anthropology, and STEM education. We developed a Theory of Change to document our guiding assumptions and expectations throughout the grant period and to define annual Faculty Learning Community goals and session-level objectives (see Image 1). Through the Faculty Learning Community, investigators guided faculty members to interrogate, reflect on, and foster their scholarly identities, values, and public purposes. Their inquiry included exploring how ethics manifested in their lives and instructional practices through the lens of applied and experiential learning, with an emphasis on civic-rich and community-engaged learning. During the first year of the Faculty Learning Community, faculty worked individually and collectively to develop deliberative department-level approaches to transforming ethics instruction and outcomes. Each department developed ethics curriculum suitable to their discipline that was experiential, emphasized practical applications, and community-engaged. An example community assignment involved scholarly identity mapping wherein participants described how they understood themselves as academic professionals, their roles as disciplinary faculty, their core values, their public purposes, values evident in their practice, broader impacts, and relationships between these aspects. Another early activity had members individually and then departmentally develop concept maps to respond to the question, "What does it mean to be become an ethical biomedical engineer/earth scientist?" Faculty responses are featured in Images 2 and 3, and these responses guided departments to autonomously integrate ethics learning throughout their curricula. Each year, participants shared learnings and progress from the prior year with campus and external stakeholders, who provided feedback. At the end of year 5, a graphic facilitator captured a visual storyboard outlining core themes and findings generated from a facilitated, deliberative discussion among department teams and stakeholders, and the resulting storyboards share each department's journey, including their priorities, strategies and resources for sustaining changes realized during the project (refer to Images 4 and 5). 

Broader Impacts: This project has facilitated the cultivation of cultures of ethical STEM at our institution that encompasses collective departmental inquiry into pedagogy, prioritizes students' ethical learning, and engages local community partners. Results from our quantitative analysis of surveys has0 suggested that participants experienced increased Self-Efficacy for Teaching Ethics and left the project Valuing Teaching Ethics to a greater extent than when they started. Results of our qualitative analysis of Faculty Learning Community participant interviews revealed shifts in how faculty members engaged with ethics in the classroom, including how they viewed and implemented ethics education in collective and continuous ways. As a result of the development of STEM educators who are confident about integrating ethical and civic-rich learning experiences, these programs at our institution realized 11 redesigned courses, one new urban field camp capstone in geosciences, and the development of ethically-literate, civic-minded, and empathic cohorts of undergraduate students. As a result of participating in I-CELER courses that were redesigned during the Faculty Learning Community, students reported experiencing opportunities to expand their ethical awareness, taking responsibility for ethical issues, and competently addressing those issues through disciplinary thought and practice. Beyond our institution, this project created a scalable modality for constructing departmental curricula that integrates community-engaged learning and philosophical ethics with STEM content (see Image 1). Our project has also led to the myriad distal outcomes, including (1) the development of curricular innovations at the departmental curriculum level focused on diversity and equity, (2) the promotion of scholarship of teaching and learning among a subset of Faculty Learning Community members, and (3) stronger relationships between IUPUI and our local community. Another key product of this work is a theoretical framework that details the processes undergirding the ethical becoming of STEM students and faculty. Beyond IUPUI, our Faculty Learning Community model, Theory of Change, this ethical becoming theoretical framework, and empirical findings will offer scalable and replicable modalities for constructing and testing departmental curriculum and faculty development efforts aimed at integrating ethics in STEM courses, thus preparing undergraduate STEM students to engage in ethical thought and action.
